channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel Postpones Vote on New Housing Ahead of Speech by John Kerry
item.media:description: Construction this week in the settlement of Har Homa in Jerusalem.
item.description: A city government committee canceled a vote on permits for homes in East Jerusalem at the request of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, members of the committee said.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: John Kerry, in a Final, Pointed Plea, Will Outline a Vision of Mideast Peace
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in September in New York. Mr. Netanyahu has clashed with Mr. Kerry and President Obama over settlements.
item.description: Mr. Kerry will use his remarks to confront Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel after bitterness over a United Nations resolution, a State Department official said.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: H.I.V. Cases Surpass a Million in Russia, but Little Is Done
item.media:description: Volunteers from the Andrey Rylkov Foundation distributing free needles, condoms and other supplies from a truck in Moscow.
item.media:credit: Max Avdeev for The New York Times
item.description: A combination of stigma and ignorance, a “family values” emphasis and government indifference have pushed H.I.V. to epidemic status.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Tunisian Detained as Possible Accomplice in Berlin Attack
item.media:description: The scene of the truck attack on a Christmas market in Berlin last week.
item.description: The man, whose name was not released, appears to be linked with Anis Amri, who is said to have driven a truck into a Christmas market, killing 12.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Senators Reassure Wary Baltic Nations That U.S. Won’t Abandon NATO
item.description: The three Baltic nations, all members of NATO and fearful of Russia, were alarmed by Donald J. Trump’s criticisms of the military alliance.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Ecatepec de Morelos Journal: Near Mexico City, Cable Car Lets Commuters Glide Over Traffic
item.media:description: A view of Ecatepec de Morelos, from the Mexicable Station #4. The Mexicable, a seven-stop line that runs just over three miles through a furrow of poor hillside neighbourhoods, is part of a growing constellation of cable cars around Latin America that link marginalized communities to their cities’ metropolitan hearts.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: The Mexicable, a new seven-stop route, allows thousands of residents to get to work or school in brightly colored pods.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner Indicted Again on Corruption Charges
item.media:description: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner in 2014 in Chile. She was indicted Tuesday on charges involving huge public works projects.
item.description: In her second indictment since she left office last year, Mrs. Kirchner, the former president of Argentina, was indicted Tuesday on charges involving huge public works projects.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI

item.title: North Korea’s Nuclear Hopes Have Surged, Defector Says
item.media:description: Thae Yong-ho
item.description: A senior North Korean official who defected to the South said the North hoped to take advantage of leadership changes in the United States and South Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Shinzo Abe at Pearl Harbor: ‘Rest in Peace, Precious Souls of the Fallen’
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, standing with President Obama on Tuesday, offered repentance but did not apologize for the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941.
item.description: The text of the Japanese prime minister’s speech at the site of the attack that drew the United States into World War II.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What in the World: Berlin Attraction Reveals an Uneasy Phenomenon: Hitler Sells
item.media:description: A replica of Hitler’s bunker in Berlin. It was built about a mile from the original site by a private company, Historiale, which also runs the Berlin Story Museum next door.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: A commercial firm has recreated the bunker where Hitler committed suicide in 1945.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Christmas Revelers Leave 16 Tons of Trash on Australian Beach
item.description: More than 10,000 people in a Sydney suburb made a huge mess, prompting a local council to ban alcohol on the beach for the rest of the Australian summer.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: Chinese Prosecutors Ask Court for More Time in Detained Tibetan’s Case
item.media:description: Tashi Wangchuk, a Tibetan entrepreneur and language education advocate, could face up to 15 years in prison if convicted of inciting separatism, which he has denied.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: The case of Tashi Wangchuk, an advocate for Tibetan language education who denies being a separatist, has attracted intense international attention.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Romania’s President Rejects First Female Candidate for Prime Minister
item.media:description: President Klaus Iohannis of Romania in Brussels this month.
item.description: Had Sevil Shhaideh been selected and confirmed, she would have also been the first Muslim to hold the office.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: In Bahrain, Arabs and Jews Gather (and Dance) at a Hanukkah Celebration
item.description: Video of the gathering in the Muslim-majority monarchy, whose king has sanctioned celebrations of the Jewish holiday, appeared on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Mehdi Karroubi, Iranian Cleric Under House Arrest, Quits Political Party
item.media:description: Mehdi Karroubi, a cleric, at a rally in 2009 in Tehran, the year he ran for president of Iran. He founded the National Trust Party in 2005, after a previous unsuccessful presidential campaign.
item.description: Mr. Karroubi, who was ordered held for his role in the 2009 Green Movement, said the detention hampered his ability to lead the National Trust Party.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: China Deploys Aircraft Carrier to Disputed South China Sea
item.media:description: Fighter jets on the deck of China’s Liaoning aircraft carrier during military drills in the Bohai Sea, off China’s northeast coast, this month.
item.description: The decision to deploy the carrier to contested waters was seen by some as a challenge to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s criticism of China and to American military dominance in the Pacific.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: School Parade in Taiwan Featuring Swastikas and Nazis Unleashes Uproar
item.media:description: A cardboard tank at the Hsinchu Kuang-Fu High School in Hsinchu City, Taiwan.
item.description: The principal resigned after photographs and images went viral online, and after the unofficial diplomatic missions of Israel and Germany issued letters of protest.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: As U.K. Tightens Voting Rules, Critics Say Labour and the Poor Will Suffer
item.media:description: A polling station in London in June. Changes to voting rules will be used first for local elections in 18 areas in May 2018.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The government announced plans to fight voter fraud by requiring voters to show official ID, tightening rules on absentee ballots and preventing political activists from handling such ballots.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: As Hopes for European Unity Dim, New E.U. Headquarters Are Glowing
item.media:description: The new European Union headquarters, the Europa, in Brussels. Ministers will move in shortly after the New Year and European Union leaders are expected to hold their first meeting there in March.
item.description: European leaders will meet in the bloc’s new home, an illuminated orb, in March, at a time when the union’s survival is being openly discussed.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Without Obama, Shinzo Abe’s Approach to U.S.-Japan Ties May Be Tested
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan in Honolulu on Monday. Given Mr. Abe’s nationalist leanings, he might not have seemed the most likely Japanese leader to embrace the United States. Yet under his leadership, Japan has committed to policies favored by the Obama administration.
item.description: Donald Trump brings uncertainty to the alliance, grumbling about trade and the cost of U.S. military support, and raising the specter of a more confrontational approach to China.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Sinosphere: Planned Hong Kong Museum Will Showcase China’s Imperial Relics
item.media:description: The Forbidden City in Beijing. Imperial treasures from the Palace Museum inside the Forbidden City will be exhibited in the Hong Kong Palace Museum, which is scheduled for completion in 2022.
item.description: The museum, which will display artifacts from the Palace Museum in Beijing, is a sign of growing cultural ties between mainland China and Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Nearly 30 Christians in Pakistan Die After Drinking Toxic Alcohol on Christmas
item.media:description: Mourning on Tuesday for a relative killed by toxic alcohol in Toba Tek Singh, Pakistan. Non-Muslims and foreigners need a permit to consume alcohol, but licensed liquor is often unaffordable for many poor Pakistanis.
item.description: Dozens more were sickened during holiday celebrations in Punjab Province, officials said. The police suspect they were drinking cheap homemade liquor.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Russian Plane’s ‘Black Box’ Found in Black Sea After Crash
item.media:description: Mourners gathered on Tuesday outside a memorial in Moscow for the Alexandrov Ensemble.
item.description: The flight data recorder may show why the Tupolev 154, which was carrying members of a military choir, crashed en route to Syria, killing 92.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: South Korea Scraps Park Geun-hye’s Contentious Textbook Policy
item.media:description: Students at a high school in Seoul, South Korea, in November. Under the abandoned proposal, middle and high schools would have been required to drop the privately published textbooks they use now in favor of government-issued ones.
item.description: The proposal, requiring the use of government-issued history textbooks, became increasingly untenable as a corruption scandal engulfed Ms. Park’s presidency.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: 2016: Worst. Year. Ever?
item.description: And you thought this was bad. History has plenty more where this one came from.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES NEVIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: A Zika Vaccine, but for Whom?
item.media:description: The Zika virus was first disovered in April 1947 near Lake Victoria in Uganda.
item.description: Far from being a threat unique to the Western Hemisphere, the virus is endemic to Africa. But that’s not where resources are going.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK ADAMS and CAMERON NUTT

item.title: Editorial: Dying in Police Custody in India
item.description: Hundreds have perished without any accountability from the police.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Italy Overwhelmed
item.description: Italy is overwhelmed by the influx of migrants. But three citizens are making a difference in migrants’ lives, and even in their deaths.
item.dc:creator: DAN RUETENIK
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
